Building from scratch? Get rid of it, NPV. (Or, yknow, parliamentarism.) The federalism benefits are minimal and messy at best.

From the status quo, the NPV compact, or else a combination of increasing the size of the House plus encouraging more states to split EV by district.

text:
Absolutely not. Been writing about the justifications for federalism for many years. It’s part of what I do for a living.

https://www.google.ca/search?q=%22jacob+t+levy%22+federalism&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&hl=en-ca&client=safari …

text:
The theory of the Electoral College: Councils of the wisest and most virtuous citizens in each state will assemble in the state capitals to deliberate about who is wise and virtuous enough to be president.

The reality: The most important voter in the country is Florida Man.
author: jtlevy

text: The problem that the EC allows Florida Man to choose the president is a different problem from the vast disproportion in voting weight between Wyoming and California,
author: jtlevy

text: The partisan preferences of Wyoming, Alaska, and South Dakota get a lot of weight in the EC, but people conflate that with "presidential candidates caring about and campaigning in those places." Candidates take those places for granted. (Delaware & RI, too.)
author: jtlevy

text:
A thing it's hard to talk about quickly:

In one sense, the EC massively overweights the power of very small population states, most of which are very rural.

But in another sense, they're not swing states, and the EC empowers [small majorities in large] swing states: FL, OH.
author: jtlevy

text: So sorry.
author: jtlevy

text: Same.
author: jtlevy

text: On NPR Morning Edition this morning discussing the Electoral College.
author: jtlevy

text:
If the new normal is Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota as permanent swing states, that would be true. 

But the key swing states for a long time have been Florida and Ohio, with Virginia, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Pennsylvania in the mix as well. Well and truly not flyover.
author: jtlevy

text: It is. The council of the wise model could only work in the absence of parties and it was undermined almost *immediately* by the rise of parties; it was dead by 1800. The handful of elections with three-plus substantial parties just saw three-plus slates of partisan electors.
author: jtlevy

text: Definitely no. Every modern state with a democratic/ republican form of government is a party system, regardless of voting rules. Voting rules affect how many parties, not whether elections are fundamentally partisan contestation. Non-FPTP systems have *more* parties, not fewer.
author: jtlevy

text:
is utterly unsustainable. And a president, in order to be able to function as head of government, will have to be in and of a party.

Ought implies can. 

(Nor do I believe in the likely existence and selection of 538 nonpartisan wise and virtuous people via the first round.)
author: jtlevy

text:
The objections to parties have. We have learned something the Founders didn't know:a representative system in a large pluralistic modern state will be, as far as we can tell must be, partisan. 
Indirect selection via councils of the nonpartisan wise of the most powerful office...
author: jtlevy

text: That's relevant when talking about, say, the Virginia and Kentucky Resolutions a decade later, not when we're talking about the Electoral College. Madison didn't change his mind on the principle "states don't count, voters do" over the course of summer 1787.
author: jtlevy

text: Including all three authors of the Federalist.
author: jtlevy

text: Madison supported popular election of the president; the EC was a compromise. And the institution created by that compromise was entirely unlike the status quo.
author: jtlevy

text:
That's not how campaigns work within states, all of which select their governor by direct popular election. 

And in the status quo, *most* campaigning is in swing states, which "flyover country" mostly isn't.
author: jtlevy

text: Well, right, it's only an argument against those who claim to support the status quo on constitutionalist grounds.  It would require other arguments (which I think are available) to show that the original model is unrecoverable.
author: jtlevy

text: Hearing from a lot of pretend constitutionalists whose defense of the Electoral College consists entirely of Founder-deference, as if the institution as it exists has anything to do with the free nonpartisan deliberation of the wise and virtuous to prevent demagogues. cf Fed 68.
